Authors:
Alice Ledent, Aurélie Désamoré , Benjamin Laenen, Patrick
Mardulyn, Stuart Frazier McDaniel, Jairo Patiño, Alain
Vanderpoorten
Title:
No borders during the post-glacial assembly of European
bryophytes
Abstract:
Climatic fluctuations during the Pleistocene exerted a
profound influence on biodiversity patterns, but their impact on
bryophytes, the second most diverse group of land plants, has been
poorly documented. Coalescent simulations integrating species
distribution models and population genetics showed that the post-glacial
assembly of European bryophytes involves a complex history from multiple
sources. The contribution of allochtonous migrants is estimated at
95-100% of extant populations in about half of the investigated species,
which is consistent with the globally balanced genetic diversities and
extremely low divergence observed among biogeographic regions. Such a
substantial contribution of allochtonous migrants in the post-glacial
assembly of European bryophyte floras is unparalleled in other plants
and animals. The limited role of northern micro-refugia, which was
unexpected based on bryophyte life-history traits, and of southern
refugia, is consistent with recent paleontological evidence that the
full-glacial landscape of Eurasia was largely treeless.
